topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Crystal recounts joining Gojek very early, including the risky leap and the company’s rapid growth even at small scale. Lenny introduces Crystal’s background and what the episode will cover.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Amplitude (analytics) and Flatfile (CSV/data onboarding), including why onboarding and data import reliability matter for conversion and retention.

topics.title: Crystal’s nontraditional path into product and growth
topics.summary: Crystal describes moving from investment banking research into tech by teaching herself databases, then cold-emailing Gojek and moving to Indonesia. She explains how she built data, fraud/risk, performance marketing, and eventually growth functions.

topics.title: Gojek and Kumu scale, and super-app dynamics
topics.summary: Crystal explains Gojek/GoTo’s scale and breadth of services, and positions Kumu as a social “super app.” They discuss why super apps emerged in Southeast Asia but not the US (trust in conglomerates, mobile-first constraints, limited device storage).

topics.title: Scrappy growth: doing things that don’t scale
topics.summary: Crystal shares scrappy tactics from Gojek: stadium hiring, Wizard-of-Oz tests via WhatsApp groups, vouchers, in-app message mock screens, and Typeform-based feature tests. Core idea: validate hypotheses with real user behavior before building.

topics.title: Experimentation at tiny sample sizes
topics.summary: Crystal argues startups should run experiments even with ~30 users: trends are directionally useful even if precision is low. She emphasizes breaking down retention into concrete preceding steps and decision barriers like trust.

topics.title: Retention and conversion: what to optimize and why
topics.summary: They discuss why “retention” is often too vague, and how improving the step right before conversion can lift retention. Crystal shares benchmarks (e.g., week-1 retention targets) and cautions about misleading early growth signals in new markets.

topics.title: Growth strategy framework: physics, constraints, and loops
topics.summary: Crystal outlines a practical growth-modeling process: define the “physics” (market/product/model/channels), identify constraints and underused levers, then improve one variable at a time. Example: leveraging drivers as a real-world acquisition channel and as sales for GoPay.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Eppo, an experimentation platform, highlighting faster analysis, slicing results, and support for north-star metrics across surfaces.

topics.title: Applying the framework to Kumu’s social product
topics.summary: Crystal explains why social growth is harder to measure than transactional products: success is emotional and implicit (friendship/community). Kumu uses intentional friction (questionnaires/forms) to segment intent and identify meaningful user paths.

topics.title: Big growth unlocks: copy, familiarity, and churn reduction
topics.summary: Crystal shares examples of impactful growth wins: improving copy and mental models (e.g., representing a wallet as a familiar “card”), and reducing churn by adding “pause” instead of forcing cancellation. Emphasis on solving the real user problem at the constraint point.

topics.title: Why analytics efforts fail: insights vs measurements
topics.summary: Crystal explains that dashboards often become “entertainment” instead of decision-changing information. She distinguishes observations from actionable insights by adding context, segmentation, and hypotheses that lead to changed behavior and experiments.

topics.title: Instrumentation quality: event properties and context
topics.summary: Crystal describes how to spot bad tracking (many events, few/no properties) and what good instrumentation looks like (capturing experience context like supply, location, pricing, vouchers). She recommends mapping user decisions and tracking the “why” drivers.

topics.title: Recommended analytics stack by company stage
topics.summary: Crystal suggests tooling based on maturity: lightweight dashboards (Data Studio/Metabase), mobile event tracking (CleverTap), CDP/pipe needs (Segment), and experimentation (Eppo).

topics.title: How to set up and evolve a growth team
topics.summary: Using Gojek as an example, Crystal explains growth as filling critical gaps alongside core product work (onboarding, OTP delivery, first-time user education). Over time, growth PMs embed into teams and mature into owners of specific product areas.
